content.description: This is a rope-stretcher. Use a 70 meter rope.

This climb is really hard to read and has tons of slopers and off balance moves. The rock is vibrant orange and very textured due to the calcification from the waterfall. There is a midway anchor on it, and from what I heard, the second pitch may have never been freed.
content.protection: Bolts, a midway anchor, and an upper anchor with loweroffs.
content.location: The climb is located directly behind the waterfall and is the first route to the right of the mine shaft. The first pitch climbs a faint orange dihedral, and the second pitch climbs the corner crack above.

content.description: The climb done in memory of Jack Mileski, the wall's name sake. This route can be done in one long pitch or 2 pitches, 5.13b and 5.12c/d respectively.
content.protection:
P1- 10 bolts to anchors.

P2- 7 bolts to anchors.

content.description:
I am only adding this because it isn't listed. Jonathan Siegrist in 2020 put this up to the right of

Renaissance Man

. He said it's 40m long, which makes no sense to me, because a 70m should cover everything on this wall, but I didn't feel like getting into an argument on youtube about it, so someone can clarify if it is in fact more than 35m. I do not remember anything requiring more than a 70m rope at God's Crag at all.

Otherwise, this is a super clean route if you can catch it dry. Like most stuff at God's Crag, grades are generally stout, and this is unlikely to receive a lot of traffic.

If you want to see his video, it's available here, very much beta in it if that's any consideration, but beautiful filming of the area and several routes:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5fUZQ1iHu10

.

Climb hard moves on a steep section just after the anchors of

C.C.V.

, then keep it together to the chains.
content.location:
This is an extension to

C.C.V.

content.description: Follows the black streak up the overhanging wall

One of the shortest routes on the wall and farthest to the left before the cave area.

Features fun moves on tack like stone, and a spanny compression crux.

Probably one of the better routes around.

If it were at rifle, it'd be a classic...
content.location: 2nd route left of the old mine shaft.

content.description:
Small boulder problem low that leads to a choss-ledge rest- then good sequence of flowing moves that negotiates a hollow tufa, some pockets, and a dihedral finish.

*Hardware could use an update on this one, as well as a crowbar to some loose holds that have weakened over the years
content.location:
Between

Man Thing

and

Woman Thing

.

content.description:
Beautiful and Savage Country is a new route on the right side of the Mileski Wall, situated in the black streak to the left of

"Barnacle Bill" on some bullet stone

This begins on 3 bolts of easy terrain up a ramp before the route takes on a series of technical movement on incuts, pockets, and slopers before reaching a good shake/rest.

After copping a rest at the ledge, maneuver up some more technical terrain on decent holds while a building pump.

The route culminates with a rad final crux sequence before the chains, featuring a techy gaston, pocket, and some choice foot holds.

This route is one of the best at the crag. It could use some more traffic to clean up some small foot holds here and there, but it is not to be missed when visiting God's Crag.

*The crux bolt hanger is already coming loose as the nut has backed off a bit. If you find yourself reading this, please bring a wrench, and tighten it.
content.protection: Bolts and a Mussy hook anchor.
content.location:
Just left of "

Barnacle Bill

," this route is identified by a line of new looking wedge bolts on the black streak of stone.

content.description: Strenuous climb that follows a broken crack and corner to an overhang. Traverse left and go over the roof to the anchors.
content.location: Right of the dark, black streak and under the overhang.
